current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To enhance consumer access to electricity information and allow for the adoption of innovative
			 products and services to help consumers manage their energy usage.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act
E-Access Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
In this Act, the term

header.#text:
Consumer
		access to electric energy information

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall encourage and support the adoption of
		policies that allow electricity consumers access to their own electricity
		data.

to enhance

header.#text:
Voluntary
		guidelines for electric consumer access

text.#text:
In
		this subsection:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act/s:3/ss:c/p:1/sp:A/cl:i

text.#text:
the
		retail electric energy prices or rates applied to the electricity usage for the
		defined time period described in

the
		estimated cost of service by the consumer, including (if smart meter usage
		information is available) the estimated cost of service since the last billing
		cycle of the consumer; and

in the
		case of nonresidential electric meters, any other electrical information that
		the meter is programmed to record (such as demand measured in kilowatts,
		voltage, frequency, current, and power factor).
The term

measures electric
		energy consumption by an electric consumer at the home or facility of the
		electric consumer in intervals of 1 hour or less; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act/s:3/ss:c/p:2

text.#text:
meets
		the guidelines issued under

term.#tail:
means the device used by
		an electric utility that—

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act/s:3/ss:c/p:2/sp:B

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall issue voluntary
		guidelines that establish model standards for implementation of retail electric
		energy information access in States.

text.#text:
Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of
		this Act, subject to

consult
		with—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
National Institute of Standards and
		Technology

text.#text:
other
		appropriate Federal agencies, including the

consumer and
		privacy advocacy groups;
utilities;

the
		National Association of State Energy Officials; and

other
		appropriate entities, including groups representing commercial and residential
			 building owners and groups that represent demand response and electricity
			 data devices and services; and

provide notice
		and opportunity for comment.

Before
		issuing the voluntary guidelines, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall, to the maximum extent practicable, be guided by actions taken
		by State and local regulatory authorities to ensure electric consumer access to
		retail electric energy information, including actions taken after consideration
		of the standard established under

text.#text: In issuing the voluntary guidelines, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 111(d)(17) of the Public Utility
		Regulatory Policies Act of 1978
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978/s:111/ss:d/p:17

text.#text:
the
		timeliness and specificity of retail electric energy information;

appropriate
		nationally recognized open standards for data;

the protection of
		data security and electric consumer privacy, including consumer consent
		requirements; and

issues relating to access of electric energy information for owners and managers of multitenant
			 commercial and residential buildings.

The voluntary guidelines shall provide guidance on issues
		necessary to carry out this subsection, including—

retail electric
		energy information should be made available to electric consumers (and third-party
			 designees of the electric consumers) in the United States—

as
		timely as is reasonably practicable;

at the
		level of specificity that the data is transmitted by the meter or as is
		reasonably practicable; and

in
		the case of an electric consumer that is served by a smart meter that can also
		communicate energy usage information to a device or network of an electric
		consumer or a device or network of a third party authorized by the consumer,
		the feasibility should be considered of providing to the consumer or third-party
			 designee, at a minimum, access to usage information (not including price
		information) of the consumer directly from the smart meter;

retail electric
		energy information should be provided by the electric utility of the consumer
		or such other entity as may be designated by the applicable electric retail
		regulatory authority;

retail electric
		energy information of the consumer should be made available to the consumer
		through a website or other electronic access
		authorized by the electric consumer, for a period of at least 13 months after
		the date on which the usage occurred;

consumer access
		to data, including data provided to owners and managers of commercial and
			 multifamily buildings with multiple tenants, should not interfere with or
			 compromise the integrity, security, or
		privacy of the operations of a utility and the electric consumer;

electric energy
		information relating to usage information generated by devices in or on the
		property of the consumer that is transmitted to the electric utility should be
		made available to the electric consumer or the third-party agent designated by the
		electric consumer; and

the same
		privacy and security requirements applicable to the contracting utility should
		apply to third-party agents contracting with a utility to process the customer data
		of that utility.

The
		voluntary guide­lines shall include guidance that—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall periodically review and, as necessary, revise the voluntary
		guidelines to reflect changes in technology, privacy needs, and the market for
		electric energy and services.
